Index
A) Bone Marrow Biopsy and Aspirate Request/ Referral
B) Agreement by Approved Practitioners
Purpose

This document is intended to provide guidance for nurse-led Bone Marrow Biopsy procedures to ensure that accurate techniques are used in order to obtain an adequate sample and a suitable specimen for processing.
Background
Examination of the bone marrow is a valuable diagnostic test to evaluate haematological disorders. Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy is also used to stage lymphoproliferative disorders.

Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy is also useful in the diagnostic investigations of pyrexia of unknown origin (PUO). It may reveal infections, such as tuberculosis, Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare (MAI), histoplasmosis, leishmaniasis, and other disseminated fungal infections. However, bone marrow aspiration and biopsy is rarely done for these indications. It may be useful in establishing the diagnosis of storage diseases, such as Niemann-Pick disease and Gaucher disease.

Finally, it can be a valuable tool in diagnosing metastatic non-haemopoietic malignancies that have spread to the bone marrow when all other imaging and diagnostic modalities have failed or when a leuco-erythroblastic peripheral blood picture is present.
Scope
This procedure is generally performed in a day case setting within a room on the Day Therapies Unit (C351). On occasions, when patients are admitted, the procedure can be performed on the ward.
Patients presenting with complaints listed in 2.2 are referred for a bone marrow biopsy on initial assessment by the Consultant Haematologist.

The target group of patients is adults (18+). Suitability for the procedure is determined by the consultant haematologist at the time of referral, this is reassessed by the operator at time of the procedure.
Contraindications and Cautions for Bone Marrow Biopsy
Patients who are excluded from this procedure include
those with haemophilia or related coagulation disorders and infection involving the biopsy area
patients receiving oral anticoagulants should have INR values below their therapeutic range prior to biopsy
Thrombocytopenia is not a contraindication, but care should be taken to avoid trauma that is more significant than usual.
Pre-procedure Protocol

Clotting screen must be requested by the referring Consultant at the point of making a referral (not needed for patients on DOAC). Recent clotting screen must be reviewed by the practitioner before performing the procedure. Patients should be advised to stop warfarin 3 days prior to the procedure and no bridging except for metallic heart valves or other exceptional cases, in which case consultant opinion is to be asked.

The Consultant Haematologist will assess the patient as suitable for bone marrow biopsy to achieve diagnosis. At this time the Consultant will supply the patient with the patient information leaflet (Appendix A) plus any necessary blood tests forms, FBC (full blood count) and clotting screen. The patient is then referred for a Bone Marrow Biopsy using the intended referral forms. (Refer to Appendix B)

Written patient consent must be obtained prior to the procedure by the operator undertaking the procedure, with additional consent to be obtained for the taking and storing of images by the Medical Photography department. (Refer to 04080 Consent Policy)
The practitioner will discuss the necessity of a bone marrow biopsy with the patient; how it will be achieved, the risks involved and potential side effects.
Sites for Bone Marrow Aspiration
The following are the safe and preferred sites for bone marrow aspiration and bone marrow biopsy:
Posterior superior iliac crest (both aspiration and biopsy)
Anterior iliac crest (both aspiration and biopsy, however not performed by nurses)
Sternum (aspiration only in adults, however not performed by nurses)
Aspiration and Biopsy from the Posterior Iliac Crest Procedure
The patient is placed in the lateral decubitus position, with both legs bent upwards towards the chest. The patient may also be placed flat on his/her stomach if preferred.
Wear sterile gloves and prepare the site with antiseptic (chloroprep) scrub
Drape the site, exposing only the biopsy area.

The skin and the area down to the periosteum are infiltrated with a local anaesthetic (2% lignocaine) using a 10ml syringe with a 25Gx1'' safety needle for the subcutaneous area and a 21Gx 1 1/2” safety needle for the remaining area. Approximately 5 to 10ml of 2% lignocaine is used. This can be extended to 15ml of 2% lignocaine but only in exceptional cases.
If required, a small incision can be made using a surgical scalpel, through which the bone marrow aspiration and biopsy needles are inserted.
The bone marrow aspiration needle, with a stylet in place, is inserted. Once the needle contacts the bone, it is advanced by rotating clockwise and counter-clockwise slowly until
the cortical bone is penetrated and the marrow cavity is entered. Usually, a sudden change in give is noted when the marrow cavity has been entered.
Once within the marrow cavity, the stylet is removed, using a syringe approximately 1- 2ml of bone marrow is aspirated for pathology slides.

If additional marrow is needed for cytogenetics or cell markers, these subsequent specimens are obtained by attaching a new syringe and aspirating the required amount of marrow to be placed in the appropriate tube (as directed on the request form).

Once the aspiration is completed the marrow aspiration needle is removed, pressure is applied to the site with gauze until bleeding has stopped. Following this procedure, a bone marrow biopsy is usually performed as well (see below).
Bone marrow Trephine Biopsy Procedure
A trephine needle is used for this procedure. The patient preparation is the same as for bone marrow aspiration. Usually, the biopsy is obtained immediately after the bone marrow aspiration.
8.1.1 The needle is held with the palm and index finger, and the stylet is locked in place.
8.1.2 Once the needle touches and penetrates the bone by about 1mm, the stylet is removed.

8.1.3 Using firm pressure, slowly rotate the needle in an alternating clockwise-counter- clockwise motion and advance it into the bone marrow cavity to obtain an adequate bone marrow specimen measuring approximately 1.5-2 cm in length. Rotate the needle along its axis and secure the specimen.
8.1.4 Following this procedure, slowly pull the needle out while rotating in an alternating clockwise and counter-clockwise motion.
8.1.5 Remove the specimen from the needle with the probe supplied by introducing the probe through the distal cutting end.
8.1.6 Place the specimen in formalin solution for histology processing. The core biopsy may be used to make touch preparations prior to placing the specimen in formalin.
8.1.7 It is the duty of the operator to ensure the correct labelling of all samples obtained.
After the procedure, gauze is applied to the site with ‘Cosmopore' on top to immobilize the gauze.
The patient is instructed to lay on his/her back following the procedure in order to apply pressure to the site. This can be 5-30 minutes as required and dependant on patient recovery.
The patient is asked to check the site frequently, to report any bleeding, and to keep it clean and dry for 24 hours. After this time the dressing can be removed.

All unexpected adverse effects relating to the procedure will be reported to the specialist who performed the procedure via the hospital bleep system or by contacting the clinical nurse specialist on 01245 514702.
Outcome
Depending on the indication for the bone marrow aspiration and biopsy, the samples are sent to either MEHT lab locally or to St Bartholomew's Hospital, London for the appropriate tests and analysis.
Results of biopsy are then discussed at the multi-disciplinary team (MDT) meeting where diagnosis and treatment plan is agreed.
Failed biopsy
9.3.1 Operator is to make sure of the quality of aspirate by obtaining bony fragments and making appropriate thickness smears.

9.3.2 A dry aspiration tap could be due to poor technique. In this case, repeat needle placement may help. A dry aspiration tap also can be observed in infiltrating bone marrow conditions (e.g. myelofibrosis, haematological malignancies, metastatic malignancies).
9.3.3 If sample obtained is inadequate or unsatisfactory, the practitioner will seek further advice from the Consultants.
9.3.4 If patient is intolerant of the procedure, the practitioner will review with the referring Consultant.
Equipment for Bone Marrow Procurement
Site Preparation
Chloroprep
Gauze
Apron
Latex gloves, sterile
Lignocaine hydrochloride, Injection, 2%, 10 ml vials
Needles (Blunt Filter needle, 25G x 1” and 21G x 1½'')
Utility drapes, sterile,
Dressing pack, sterile
Marrow Procurement
Bone marrow aspiration needles,
Bone marrow biopsy needles,
Disposable plastic syringes, sterile
Disposable plastic syringes, sterile
Disposable scalpel
EDTA tube
Formalin tube
Cytogenetics tube (if required)
Cell markers tube (if required)
Microscope slides
Wound care
Gauze
Cosmopore
Staffing and Training
This procedure is performed by Specialist Nurses and Foundation Year 2 junior doctors and above, who have been trained, assessed and deemed competent by the Consultant Haematologists (Appendix C).
Safety
Resuscitation facilities should be available. There should be at least one other trained staff (medical/nursing) present, should assistance be required.
A tray containing drugs used in the treatment of anaphylaxis should be available within the Department.
Risk Events/Error Reporting
Staff will report all adverse reactions occurring during the procedure via Datix.
Staff will report via Datix, all instances where the policy is not followed including “near misses”.
Audit and Monitoring
The Haematology Team will review the outcomes of the procedures weekly at the MDT and present an annual review of the service to the Trust.
Quarterly audits will demonstrate clinical guidelines have been followed by recording complication rates as well as outcomes.
The audit will be reviewed by the haematology team and at appraisal with Line Manager.
Equality and Diversity
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
Implementation and Communication
After ratification, a copy of the guideline is published on the Trust intranet and website.
The author is responsible for ensuring that personal copies are emailed to all the staff responsible for implementing this guideline.
